question: What do both hurricanes and tornadoes always have?

content.source_1: In the Northern Hemisphere, hurricanes (tropical cyclones) consistently spin counterclockwise because of the Coriolis effect acting on large-scale low-pressure systems.
content.source_2: Supercell thunderstorms in the Northern Hemisphere contain mesocyclones that rotate counterclockwise.
content.source_3: Most tornadoes develop from those rotating supercell updrafts, and tornadoes that form from a cyclonic mesocyclone inherit its counterclockwise spin.
content.source_4: Meteorological records document anticyclonic (clockwise) tornadoes in the Northern Hemisphere, although they are relatively rare.
content.source_5: At the spatial scale of a tornado, the Coriolis force is negligible; tornado vortex rotation can be either cyclonic or anticyclonic depending on storm-scale vorticity and storm interactions.
content.source_6: Hurricanes require the Coriolis effect to organize and maintain their circulation, which is why they seldom form within about 5 degrees of the equator and why their Northern Hemisphere rotation is counterclockwise.
